BE

Here's Caz.

11:10 am
BE

As previously indicated
on 9th Feb, Kumba has received a tax assessment from the South African
Revenue Service (“SARS”) relating to the period 2006-10. SARS claims
ZAR 1.8bn of unpaid tax ($115m) and ZAR 3.7bn ($230m) in interest and
unpaid penalties. The tax claim is in line with the ZAR 1.8bn indicated by
Kumba on 9th Feb, but penalties were not provided at that time. On 9th Feb,
Kumba also indicated that SARS was in the process of conducting a field
audit for the years 2011-13.

BE

If pursued by
SARS, we believe this claim could complicate Anglo American’s plans to
sell or spin out its 70% interest in Kumba. Not least since we believe the
South African authorities are likely to require Kumba to be debt free as part
of Anglo American’s exit. In Feb’16, Anglo American indicated Kumba is
likely to be debt free at YE’16 at current iron ore prices, which could be
jeopardised if cash outflows arise under this tax claim.

BE

Kumba's CEO states “As a responsible corporate
citizen, Kumba and its subsidiaries believe all taxes owed under South
African tax legislation have been paid and that we comply with all
applicable tax laws in all jurisdictions in which we operate. In 2015
alone, a year during which the iron ore price fell sharply, our business
contributed ZAR 900m in corporate taxes & mineral royalties, ZAR
4.7bn in salaries & wages, ZAR 15.2bn in local procurement, ZAR 6.8bn
of capital reinvested in the business and ZAR 174m in social investment
in health, housing, education and small business development.” Kumba is
in the process of preparing an objection to the assessment, together with an
application to the Commissioner of SARS for a suspension of payment until
the matter is resolved.

11:10 am
BE

Anglo American has potential long-term value, as evidenced by
our base case P/NPV of 0.75x, but this hinges on a recovery in commodity
prices and the execution of its proposed restructuring. We remain sceptical
on management’s ability to execute its plan, due to Anglo’s unique political
and social responsibilities in South Africa.

BE

Still no good reason to own Anglo.

Ocado is pleased to announce that it has agreed headline terms with Morrisons for it to share some of the capacity of Ocado's customer fulfilment centre ("CFC") currently under construction in Erith, south east London. Under these terms Ocado will also provide Morrisons with the software necessary to fulfil online orders from its stores, primarily intended to enable online services in areas not currently serviced by a CFC.

WM Morrison Supermarkets PLC (MRW:LSE): Last: 196.50, up 8.6 (+4.58%), High: 200.70, Low: 194.40, Volume: 6.96m

Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 254.00, down 27.9 (-9.90%), High: 274.18, Low: 253.60, Volume: 1.45m
BE

Let me get some sellside.

BE

UBS has a quick summary.

11:17 am
PM

Do share

PM

if you can

BE

The good news: Morrisons this morning has announced they intend to take capacity
in Ocado's fourth distribution centre (operational at the end of 2017) in Erith (SE
London). There was some concern that Morrisons still relatively new management team
would look to break ties with Ocado (the original deal was signed by the old team)
which would have been seen as damaging to Ocado's prospects of signing a new
partner. Ocado has said that once the agreement is signed, they'll help Morrisons
develop software to do some picking from stores in areas not reached by CFCs.

11:17 am
BE

The bad news: Morrisons has also said this morning that it is to supply 'hundreds of
products' to Amazon (for Pantry and Prime Now). In our view, we don't see Amazon as
a significant near-term threat to the full grocery service offered by Ocado (prices are
higher and the range is much, much smaller) but further investment in Pantry could be
a precursor to a fuller offer, albeit, perhaps years away.

BE

On balance: we suspect Ocado's shares will be negatively impacted this morning.
However, in our view, the extension of the deal by Morrisons is good news and
outweighs the negative of further progress at Amazon Pantry which was, to a degree,
inevitable anyway. The deal with Amazon is a small positive for Morrisons we think.

BE

And Credit Suisse.

11:18 am
BE

■ Impact on Morrisons: Positive. We view this as a very good deal for
Morrisons, although we do not have an estimate of how fast the ramp up
will be. The deal requires no capital, volumes will be incremental, operating
leverage will increase and it helps optimise their “upstream” manufacturing
assets – assets that we have, up to now, been sceptical of. The deal is not
exclusive, but we do not see Tesco, Sainsbury or Asda as being credible
partners with Amazon given the much higher cannibalisation potential.

BE

■ Impact on Tesco: Negative. Tesco is the market leader in online grocery,
with over £4bn in sales and nearly 50% market share. However, as
mentioned in our recent note on online economics, we believe Tesco is
losing money on virtually every delivery.

Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 178.52, down 5.63 (-3.06%), High: 182.05, Low: 176.95, Volume: 7.79m
11:19 am
BE

In terms of losing money on delivery, there was some survey last year that put the delivery cost loss at £3 to £5, giving a total industry loss from online grocery at £300m.

PM

Brilliant

BE

I'd have that to hand, had Adobe Acrobat not crashed two minutes ago.

11:20 am
BE

Though a lot depends on where you put the costs. I mean, supermarkets need warehouses anyway. It's not simple, and grocery CEOs shy away from giving specifics.

BE

Back to Credit Suisse.

BE

■ Impact on Sainsbury: Negative. We believe the announcement increases
the likelihood of a firm, higher bid for the Home Retail Group. What is
unclear is whether today’s announcement also prompts Tesco or Asda to
enter the competition for HRG, as the benefits highlighted by Sainsbury are
common to both. Tesco and Asda also have deeper pockets.

11:20 am
J Sainsbury PLC (SBRY:LSE): Last: 249.90, down 2.9 (-1.15%), High: 251.70, Low: 249.20, Volume: 1.20m
Home Retail Group PLC (HOME:LSE): Last: 176.20, down 0.7 (-0.40%), High: 178.40, Low: 175.20, Volume: 728.99k
BE

■ Impact on Ocado – Mixed: The initial reaction to an AmazonFresh launch
is clearly negative, although we suspect some of the stock price movement
has already been priced in. Most importantly, it shows that Amazon is
serious, and will serve notice to CEOs and CFOs globally that while signing
onto Ocado's Smart Platform is complicated, waiting until Amazon decides
to launch in your home territory is a lot more worrying.

Anyway, here's what Genel might now be worth.

11:30 am
BE

Citi incoming.

BE

Significant downgrade to reserves at its core Taq Taq asset
Genel has reduced the expected gross ultimate recovery from its Taq Taq field from 683mbbls to 356mbbls due to revised assumptions on the fracture porosity within the Shiranish reservoir at the field. As a result of this reserve downgrade, Genel also expects to record an impairment of c.US$1bn due to a lower carrying value for the Taq Taq field in its FY15 results, which is c.28% of its current equity value. Our Buy-case on Genel was based on a view that despite the political uncertainties in the Kurdistan region, Genel held a significant low cost resource base that was undervalued and remained relevant to the wider industry. However, the news today changes this investment thesis and also makes it more challenging for Genel to fund its Miran gas development, in our view. We reduce our core NAV to 120p/share and downgrade Genel Energy to Neutral/High Risk (2H).
Recoverable resource at the Tawke field will be questioned
The cut to the Taq Taq resource base creates increased uncertainty on the underlying assumptions (and ultimate resource recovery) at the DNO-operated Tawke field. DNO is currently preparing an updated resource report for the Tawke field. We have increased the risking of the valuation of the Tawke field to 85% (from 90%) in our Genel NAV.
Ability to fund its major gas development becomes more challenging
With a significant cut to reserves and consequently future cashflows from its core Taq Taq field, we believe the ability for Genel to finance the development of its Miran/Bina Bawi gas development becomes more challenging. Genel has estimated upstream capex of c.US$1bn before first gas. We have moved our valuation of Genel’s gas development from core NAV to base NAV given this uncertainty.
Updating NAV and estimates, downgrading to Neutral
We have lowered our core NAV to 120p/share to reflect the lower reserves at Taq Taq, increased risking of the Tawke field moving the Miran/Bina Bawi gas field into base NAV. With continued political uncertainty (and ongoing pipeline issues), we believe Genel could trade at a discount to core NAV in the near-term.

BE

And Barclays.

11:30 am
BE

Our view: Although a reserve downgrade at Taq Taq was previously flagged and therefore should have been widely anticipated, we believe the scale of the cut is likely to surprise many investors. Trading at a 48% discount to our current 237p/share Core NAV, versus a peer group average premium to Core NAV of 9% we believe the stock was already pricing in a significant portion of the reserve cut.
Taq Taq gross 2P reserves have been reduced from 683mmbbls to 356mmbbls on an estimated ultimate recovery basis. With 184mmbbls produced by the end of 2015, remaining gross 2P reserves now stand at 172mmbbls. The cut – following an internal review and updated Competent Person’s Report – therefore represents a 65% cut in remaining 2P reserves versus the current assumption within our Genel NAV. We have previously stated that a 25% cut in reserves would result in a ~20% reduction in our valuation of the asset – Genel’s 44% stake in Taq Taq is the company’s most material asset within our 320p/share Tangible NAV.
Genel expect completion of the updated CPR shortly, but have stated the reserve downgrade should have no impact on 2016 production guidance of 60-70,000b/d. Taq Taq is forecast to produce 80,000b/d gross in 2016, but is then scheduled to decline in 2017-18. Our current valuation assumes a ramp-up to ~150,000b/d.
The reserve update combined with a lower oil price outlook is set to result in a ~$1bn impairment charge on the asset in Genel’s FY15 results, due to be published on 3 March.

PM

That's a tad understated

undefined
11:32 am
PM

Some grey on China starting to land in my inbox

PM

How about Cap Economics

PM

They've been a bit on the back foot of late -- on China

11:33 am
PM

The People’s Bank has cut the required reserve ratio (RRR) for all banks by 50bp. That takes the RRR for major banks to 17.0%. The move underscores a message that officials have repeated in recent days, including at the G20 meeting: policymakers still have room to support the economy.

Over the past couple of years, the number of policy tools available to the PBOC has proliferated and it started to talk of the RRR as a tool to encourage banks to better manage risks. But an across-the-board move like this is a reversion to the previous practice of using the RRR to manage broad monetary conditions. The PBOC is also using open market operations much more intensively than in the past. The key difference is that an RRR cut delivers a permanent increase in liquidity. The statement says the move is intended to guide “stable and appropriate growth of money and credit”.

PM

There are a few implications. First, there is still a bias towards supporting the economy. Policy support in recent months has been delivered mainly through fiscal measures (e.g. tax cuts) and relaxation of controls on property. The last shift in the high profile monetary tools was in October, when both the RRR and benchmark rates were cut. We expect one more RRR cut by the end of Q2 and also think the benchmark deposit rate could be cut a couple of times between now and then. Increasingly though, the PBOC is focusing on market interest rates. The seven-day repo is arguably now the key gauge of the monetary stance. It has been low but stable since mid-2015 but we think that, with policymakers showing a continued easing bias, it is likely to fall over coming weeks.

Second, the explicit mention in the statement of supporting credit growth is significant. After January’s huge expansion of credit, there had been suggestions that policymakers wanted to rein credit back in. A further acceleration of credit will only deepen concerns about bad debt and over-investment. But these are issues for the medium term. For now, the emphasis in on shoring up growth in the near term

PM

Finally, today’s move suggests that concerns about capital flows have eased. Earlier this year, PBOC Chief Economist Ma Jun cautioned that an across-the-board RRR cut would push down domestic interest rates and exacerbate outflows. It may be that the PBOC senses that speculative pressure has diminished or that closer monitoring of capital flows has helped slow the flow. Either way, today’s decision suggests the PBOC is more relaxed about outflows than a few weeks ago.

PM

HSBC Holdings PLC (HSBA:LSE): Last: 457.20, down 10.15 (-2.17%), High: 460.00, Low: 451.05, Volume: 10.61m
11:35 am
BE

Excellent note out of Bernstein this morning.

BE

Talking a divi cut.

BE

Which'd be catastrophic, really.

BE

And also includes $9bn of capital trapped in the US, for what we euphemistically call legacy issues.

11:37 am
PM

Jeepers didn't realise it was so stressed

BE

Yep. This isn't a bank that should be returning capital to shareholders. This isn't 2007.

BE

It's Bernstein, so I can't quote much otherwise they shout at me. So here's the intro.

11:38 am
BE

HSBC's Q4 results (quite dreadful) are symptomatic of the macro headwinds that the Global Banking system faces this year – a lack of credit demand, a sharp drop in corporate activity and a low rate environment that can only get worse. In this environment, we find it impossible for the bank to sustain its progressive dividend policy and expect the bank to signal a cut anytime in the next 6 months. For a stock that is widely held as an income stock, we feel a cut would be painful and would reset valuation significantly downwards this year. Accordingly we downgrade the stock to Underperform with a Price target of 380p

BE

And here's the conclusion.

BE

HSBC has done as well as it could within the limitations of a low rate and growth environment. The reality remains that this bank is a deposit gathering machine that depends on rates to generate more than 60bps of RoTA. Now that we have had near zero rates for ~8 years and doesn’t look like changing any time soon, it is difficult to see any upside from here. Its key money spinner – Hong Kong – is sharply slowing down and we are actually moving more towards negative rates across the world. A dividend cut would just bring home these headwinds and spook investors.

11:39 am
PM

certainly would -- spook investors

BE

Spook some income funds too. What was previously the easiest job in the city has been getting quite difficult recently.

BE

(@nichoman: I'd suggest that Bernstein's mining guy seems to be an ideas generator rather than a stock direction type. There are too few of the former, even if it can leave them looking a tad exposed at times.)

PM

BE

RSA’s alphabet suitor

How many big insurers can you name that begin with the letter ‘A’? There can’t be that many.

Actually, there are more than you think. In Europe there is Aviva, Axa, and Allianz. America has AIG, and in Asia, AIA is the dominant name. The latest rumour circulating in the City is that one of these is quietly plotting a takeover bid for RSA. The Square Mile is full of vague speculation like this that sounds like a drunken game of Chinese whispers – clearly it would be futile spending much time trying to work out whether there is much to the chatter.

11:47 am
BE

Couple of pars.

BE

Management raise the potential for the business to earn more than 50p of
earnings in future as an “ambition”. If this was likely why were management so
keen to accept 550p from Zurich? If RSA do deliver more than 50p of earnings
consistently then we expect the share price will outperform. However, the
challenge of improving the combined ratio, by lowering costs, improving
underwriting and maintaining top line seems a bit ambitious. We expect the
market will not support this level of profitability and volumes will decline.

BE

While CEO Stephen Hester was correct, I do like biscuits, but the current
valuation of RSA is too “Rich Tea” for me compared to Zurich (ZURN VX,
CHF208.40, Outperform, TP: CHF272.00)and we are downgrading RSA to
Neutral with a target price of 460p.
With a reported TNAV of 279p, the share price is already trading at 1.55x for a
target RoTE of 15% at the top of the range.

http://www.ft.com/...html#axzz41YK0ckF6

BE

A 24-hour butler service. Interiors by Versace. A swimming pool suspended mid-air between buildings. These are some of the unusual features available with new London luxury apartments, tens of thousands of which are being built all over the capital. All that is missing are the buyers.
More than 50,000 homes are planned or under construction in the most expensive areas of London — after a building boom that followed the 2008 crisis, when prime property recovered quickly and overseas buyers piled into the UK capital.

BE

Even though 2014 was a strong year for sales, only 3,900 homes worth more than £1m were sold in central London. Now, as more shiny residential towers rise on the banks of the River Thames, buyer appetite has paled.
JLL, the US-based property group, predicts that prices for new-build homes in central London will fall 3 per cent in 2016, and not rise again until 2018. Only three months ago it was forecasting a 1 per cent increase this year.

Ultra Electronics Holdings PLC (ULE:LSE): Last: 1,765, down 133 (-7.01%), High: 1,930, Low: 1,751, Volume: 76.46k
11:55 am
BE

Numbers good, fuzzy outlook.

BE

More than £100m of delayed orders causing the uncertainty.

BE

Here's UBS.

11:56 am
BE

Ultra reported FY revenues broadly in line with our and consensus expectations. The
company has seen an organic revenue decline of 8.1% vs. our expectations of a 5%-
6% decline. The underlying order book declined 12.5% - on the back of the delay into
H1 2016 of ~£100m of orders. Cash conversion came in slightly better than expected
at 77% (ex Oman) vs. our expectations of 70%. The outlook seems vague at the first
view - Ultra expects to make "satisfactory progress in 2016" vs. our expectations of
~2% organic growth, 16.7% margins and improving cash conversion.

BE

Q: How did the results compare vs. expectations?
Ultra reported group revenues of £726.3m (up 1.8%, UBSe £729m), group underlying
profit of £120m (margin 16.5%, UBSe £120.5m, Reuters cons £118.8m), and
underlying EPS of 123.9p (UBSe 120p, cons 120.6p).
Q: How would we expect investors to react?
We believe investors' focus is likely to be on: a) 2016 outlook and mid-term growth
outlook in the context of inflecting US defence budgets b) order book prospects in
2016 c) the progress on the cluster reorganization and the S3 programme.
Valuation: trading on 12.3x 16E EV/EBITA, 14.9x 16E P/E
Our 1,950p PT is based on a DCF valuation using a cash conversion of 88%, 5 years
profit growth of 4.6%, and a WACC of 9%; this implies a fair value multiple of 12.4x.

BE

And Cazenove.

11:57 am
BE

ULE reported 2015 EPS 3% ahead of BBG consensus. The outlook statement
reflects what ULE sees as an unusually uncertain economic and political
environment, with ULE guiding to 2016 organic growth between -2% and
+3%. ULE has also essentially stopped capitalising R&D which means we
reduce our 2016-18E ULE defined EPS by -3%-4%-4% pa but the JPM
defined clean EPS (which deducts capitalised R&D) only moves 0%-1%-
2%. We trim our multiples-based Dec-16 price target by c2% to 2175p,
leaving 15% potential upside. We retain our OW rating, reflecting our view
that: (1) the Western defence cycle is at the beginning of an upturn; and (2)
Defence is a relative safe haven in an environment of weakening global
growth.
 FY15 results slightly ahead of expectations: Sales of £726m were in line
with consensus (£728m). EBITA of £120m was 1% ahead of consensus.
EPS of 123.9p was c3% ahead of consensus. Net debt of £296m was in line
with consensus of £292m.
 Some orders slipped from 2015 to 2016: ULE's order book fell 12.5% in
organic terms in 2015. ULE says £100m of orders expected in 2015 slipped
into 2016. It says it is confident these orders have been will be secured in
early 2016 and that they will be incremental to the normal orders expected
in 2016.
 2016 outlook: ULE’s guidance of organic growth between -2% and +3% in
2016 is somewhat wider than we expected. We had been expecting c1%
growth but have lowered it to 0%. Investors familiar with the mechanics of
the US defence industry will already know that although the fiscal year
2016 US Defence Investment budget has been increased by 10%, the money
will not be spent (known as cash “outlays”) until 2017 and 2018.

BE

Hope that helps.

West African gold merger. Exciting.

11:58 am
PM

Board recommends acquisition by Perseus Mining; offer valued at 14.62p per Amara share (16.3p including Perseus warrants); combined entity would be well-positioned to fund Yaoure, we believe. Amara’s board is recommending an acquisition by Perseus Mining (ASX: PRU^, NR, CNP), whereby Amara shareholders receive 0.68 Perseus shares and 0.34 3-year warrants (A$0.44/share strike) for every Amara share.

PM

The companies estimate that this values Amara’s shares at 16.3p/share, assuming an A$:£ FX rate of 1.94 and each warrant being valued at 4.9p/share.
This values Amara at £68.3m, based on its 420.4m shares in issue.
Excluding the warrants, the premium over last week’s closing share price of 10.3p/share would be c.42.2%; the warrants would add an additional 16.4%.
Assuming no warrant exercise, Perseus shareholders would own 64.9% of the combined company; Amara shareholders, 35.1%; if the warrants are exercised, then the ratio becomes 55.2%:44.8%.
Perseus’s Jeff Quartermaine would become MD & CEO of the combined entity, while Amara’s John McGloin and Alex Davidson would be invited to join Perseus’s board as NEDs.

PM

We had previously cautioned that Amara was only funded to mid-2016, whereas Perseus (whose Edikan mine in Ghana produced 212koz in FY2015) has a strong balance sheet (it had positive net working capital as of December 2015 of A$164.9m). The combination should see the combined entity funded to complete the Bankable Feasibility Study (BFS) on Amara’s 100%-owned flagship Yaoure gold project in Côte d'Ivoire; we believe that much of the equity proportion of project construction funding could also potentially be funded internally, depending on the scale of project that Perseus settles upon.

11:58 am
PM

To re-cap, last week, Amara unveiled positive results from an Optimised Pre-Feasibility Study (OPFS) on Yaoure.
The OPFS envisaged a single-pit operation with a smaller 4.5Mtpa plant (Amara continues to review “other smaller plant sizes”), averaging 248koz/year in Years 1-5 or 203koz/year over a 15-year life-of-mine (LOM).
LOM All-In Sustaining Cost (AISC) was put at US$667/oz, while upfront capex was estimated at US$334m (including US$44m contingency and US$60m for an owner-operated mining fleet).
Post-tax IRR and NPV8% were estimated at 38% and US$555m, assuming a gold price of US$1,200/oz (spot is currently c.US$1,238/oz)

PM

done
